Évaluation publiée le 18 décembre 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

Playing status: 100% achievement
Grindy Achievement(s): Yes (5+ achievements).
Optional Achievement(s): Yes (~50 achievements).
Difficult Achievement(s): No.

Intro
You are a scientist that is located in a lab. Nobody knows what you are doing, but somehow, you are shrinking bit by bit. Luckily, it turns out there are antidote formulas and materials for making it hidden in the lab - you just need to find them and make the antidote yourself. Well, that's the gist of what's happening in Size Matters.

Pros:
- 6 preset levels
- Customizable levels for additional replayability

♥♥♥♥:
- It's hard to pick up items whenever you are very small
- The lack of preset levels can make the game boring after a while

Specs
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

Should you buy this game?
Yes.
If you are looking for a short and unique game, it's a nice game to spend 2-3h in. Just make sure to buy it on a sale since the game can be repetitive after you finished all preset levels.


In-Depth Review

Visuals
The game uses realistic, 3D models to present 6 lab locations. All labs look different from each other with varying colors and objects. The one and only non-lab setting, the living room, might not mesh well theme-wise, but it gives a fresh look to the game. The brown-colored pieces of furniture and wallpaper give life to the dull laboratory atmosphere that the other locations give.

The Game
Gameplay
The gameplay revolves around creating an antidote to your shrinking problem. Formulas and vials that contain materials that can be used to make the antidote will be scattered across the level, randomized for every playthrough. You need to find notes containing the formula to figure out what you must do with the materials to craft three keys that can be used to make an antidote. Three main machines will help you modify the materials, along with two others that can help you in case you screwed up.

The game can be confusing to play at first. Luckily, the tutorial is good enough to guide you through all of it. The controls can be weird at first - it took me a while to familiarize how everything works, especially with one machine that requires me to place two vials in succession for it to work. There were times that I didn't know what to do even with the tutorial, but the game gives enough time for you to familiarize yourself with the mechanics before proceeding to the main game.

Size Matters 
Une capture d'écran de Size Matters
Par : Chobbs


Although I said the main game, there isn't much to offer. Size Matters is focused on playing one level that lasts ~15 minutes with customizable configurations. A lot of modifiers can be used to change the game's difficulty, increasing replayability. As someone who doesn't like playing a game without goals, these kinds of modifier doesn't suit me at all. Luckily, the game also has 6 preset levels that you can play with varying difficulties.

The thing that I liked the most is how you can view the areas differently. Places that can be traversed easily in your normal height will be a challenge as you shrink, turning the game into a platformer of some sort. You need to use other objects as a bridge to jump to a higher spot, and transporting vials can be challenging this way since your jump height will be reduced when you are carrying an item.

Size Matters 
Une capture d'écran de Size Matters
Par : lconanl™


Length and Difficulty
Since the game doesn't have a proper length, I just went ahead and finished all levels and do an achievement hunt afterward. I spent 4.2h to get everything although I estimated around 2-3h gameplay if you only wanted to play the preset levels. Some secrets that can give you achievements are hidden in each location, increasing your playtime if you aim to get them all. You need to shrink a lot to find most of them though, which requires you to wait for a few minutes to be small enough to access the previously inaccessible spot.

I found the preset levels to be enjoyable. You can start them from any order that you want, but going from the easiest one can assure you to get used to the mechanic before attempting the harder difficulty. The harder levels can be challenging to finish, but not hard enough to make you frustrated, except for one level. I had difficulty finishing it since I didn't know the double jump mechanic that was only available in some configurations. The said level doesn't pose any trouble after I know the mechanic.

Size Matters 
Une capture d'écran de Size Matters
Par : Chobbs


I wish there are more preset levels. I'm not the type of person who enjoys playing mindlessly without goals and having a lot of preset levels helps with that. As with how the game currently stands, I didn't find the preset levels to be redundant, even if they are located in the same area; the randomization of the formula's name and location greatly helps with the replayability. People who like to modify the config will find it more enjoyable than I do and spend more time playing the game.

Problems
It's hard to clear the levels when you are tiny. You can lose grip on items quickly, whether when you want to pick up notes in a drawer or drag objects on the floor. Some objects also can get stuck on the floor and walls sometimes. This can be a nightmare if the stuck object is a note since you won't be able to see the formula that is written on it. Your only choice is to restart the game or guess what the leftover formula that the level needs.

Conclusion
As a game that has a unique concept, Size Matters executes it greatly. It focuses on customizations, offering replayability to those who seek it. However, the lack of preset levels also can be a boomerang since the game will be too short for those who don't like to play endlessly. I wished that it has more level presets to compensate for this, and include the customizations as an additional feature for those who want more instead of the other way around. Nevertheless, it is still a great time to spend the evening with, especially for those who are looking for a quick game and something unique to play.

Évaluation publiée le 7 juillet 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

I’ve always enjoyed games where you get weird perspectives on the world. Whether it’s being huge or tiny, it’s interesting to engage with the environment in a unique way. Size Matters lets you experience this dynamically while trying to accomplish a goal through a series of tasks that become increasingly difficult as your perspective changes. That alone makes it worth trying, but it might not have what it takes to stick around.

Abbreviated Review:
Vidéo YouTube™: Size Matters - The Science of Shrinkage | Abbreviated Reviews 
Vues : 460
Obviously the underlying tone of this game is the existential dread of feeling like you're shrinking in a world of ever-increasing social media connection, globalization, and climate change.


Shrinkage
Size Matters tosses you into a situation where you’re shrinking by the second. It works essentially as a timer (even though there’s also a timer) that counts down until you’re too small to do much of anything. The thing is, the whole journey to Tiny Town is marked with new issues that will make things more difficult for you. You’ll slowly be unable to see over the edge of countertops, meaning you’ll have to do most of your work on the floor. The only way you’ll be able to interact with your scientific tools is to stand on boxes and stools while reaching over your head. Of course, moving those bulky stepping-stones around also becomes harder as your stature decreases, so it’s often best to plan ahead.

On the higher difficulties, you’ll also have to contend with spilling and breaking flasks. This isn’t much of a problem when you’re bending down to pick them up, but when you’re reaching up to grab a flask that’s now almost as big as you, it’s easy to dump the entire contents on the floor. I found that this aspect of difficulty took the game to another level. When you can haphazardly throw these precious ingredients around, it’s a much lighter challenge to make your way back to being a regular-sized Rudy.

Growage
Overcoming your tininess and resolving your shrinking affliction is your end goal. Accomplishing this means finding a series of instructions strewn all across a lab in drawers, on shelves, and hidden in randomized locations. Along with those instructions, you also have to track down the starting ingredients that the instructions will instruct you to craft into an antidote.

This is a straightforward process if you can read and remember some strange chemical names, but the task of finding them all, in the beginning, instills an early sense of panic – given your decline. If you can’t find one item, you can’t succeed in making the antidote, so you may lose quite a few inches before you can even really start working.

Mixing chemicals or adding them to a device that changes them via a specific code is simple. Hell, some just require you to microwave them to complete a step in the directions. The part that makes it challenging is that it takes time to achieve those steps and every moment can mean big challenges for your little hands. Every run through this event provided just enough of a thrill to make me want to try it again on a harder difficulty, but these freeform-style experiences usually aren’t much of a motivator to keep me captivated too long.

Reshrinkability
After playing through Size Matters on all of the base difficulties, I had plenty of fun, but aside from stacking up some achievements, I don’t feel like jumping back in. Without any kind of campaign, it’s mostly about setting up your own hurdles for satisfaction – and that’s never been something that I’ve had a lot of fun with. Chasing high scores is one thing, but playing a game where you have to decide how difficult you want it to be every 15 minutes isn’t that appealing to me.

Size Matters could also use more variety. In every run, once you find the required items, you’re just putting them together in the same handful of ways. I think it would be interesting to have some more tools to use or maybe some with interactivity beyond sitting and watching a timer. Maybe something that requires you to flip switches or shake something. It would also be interesting if you had some kind of side mechanic that could temporarily increase your size or potentially shrink you faster. Just things that would shake it up.

However, even without a campaign or a great deal of replayability, Size Matters is a unique and fun experience for at least a couple of hours. I can see myself heading back in if more features are added because the core concept is well executed and fun in short bursts. Check it out if you can find it for a good price!

If you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page here: Endyo’s Indies, Abbreviated Reviews, and online at BagoGames

Die Zeit rennt, schon wieder ist das Experiment schief gelaufen. Schaffst du es in der Zeit, das Gegenmittel herzustellen oder schrumpfst du ins Nichts?

Bei Size Matters handelt es sich um ein Minigame, in dem es darum geht, das Gegenmittel für ein missglücktes Experiment herzustellen. Jedoch schrumpfst du mit jeder Sekunde und wo sind überhaupt die Reagenzien, geschweige denn die Reaktionsvorschriften?


🎮Gameplay

Das Gameplay von Size Matters ist simpel gehalten, finde die Reagenzien und kombiniere diese, um das Gegenmittel herzustellen. Die Abwechslung rührt dabei aus den unterschiedlichen Schwierigkeitsgraden sowie den verschiedenen Laboratorien. Das Spiel eröffnet die Möglichkeit von sechs Schwierigkeitsgraden. Zusätzlich kann der Spieler seine eigene Herausforderung erstellen, indem mit den verschiedenen Einstellungen experimentiert werden kann. Besonders hervorgehoben muss die Schrumpfkurve, diese kann auch variiert werden, von dem standardmäßigen linearen Schrumpfen, über einen logarithmischen Verlauf bis hin zu einer Welle.
Die Steuerung ist an sich solide und kann nach belieben in den Einstellungen angepasst werden. Herausfordernd wird die Steuerung, sobald die Flüssigkeiten verschüttet werden können. Zwar können die Kolben rotiert werden, jedoch ist es mit der Maus ein wenig hakelig und das führt oft zum Verschütten der Flüssigkeiten.

85/100


Die Kopie des Spiels wurde der GGC-Curations kostenlos zur Verfügung gestellt


🎥&🎶 Bild und Ton

Size Matters hat einen sehr sauberen graphischen Look. Die wichtigen Gegenstände heben sich von der Szenerie weit genug ab, um bemerkbar zu sein, aber sehen dabei nicht fehl am Platz aus. Die sechs unterschiedlichen Laboratorien sind alle individuell gestaltet und haben Wiedererkennungswert.
So langsam wird es aber Zeit

79/100

Produit reçu gratuitement

Size Matters
...is a race-against-the-clock puzzle game. Following an experiment going wrong, you are shrinking into nothing and must mix chemical ingredients to make an antidote before your time runs out!

⚙ Game Description & Mechanics ⚙
You begin in a lab, with ingredients and recipes randomly scattered across the room on shelves and counters, in cupboards and drawers, and you need to find each and every one of them. Some may be hidden among or behind other decorative items such as water bottles or plastic bins. In addition to the clipboards, additional recipes can be found on white boards or chalk boards on the walls, depending on the laboratory you are located in.

Following the recipe, you must use the chemical ingredients in a number of ways: mixing them with each other or with water (which you pour from the sink), process them in a code combiner, or place them in a microwave. If you ever make a mistake, you can put the result in a reverter to get your former ingredients back. If you spill or break your bottle (if the option is turned on), you can recreate it and its content from using the restorer. You must follow the trail of recipes and end up with three key chemical components to place in your antidote producer.

There are six different laboratories, ranging from a small office laboratory to an apartment loft to a workshop, each offering a very different experience: the layout of the place you walk (or rather run!) across, the placement of the equipment, the spread and quantity of drawers and cabinets your ingredients and recipes could be hidden in, or even the presence of wall-mounted boards with recipes which influences the quantity of clipboard recipes you must find.

☺ What I enjoyed ☺
Most of the fun comes from challenging yourself as you frantically run from one device to another with your chemical ingredients. Timing is key: while these two are mixing, throw the other one in the microwave and pour yourself another bottle of water while on your way! The smaller you get, the harder it is to carry stuff around or even to reach countertops to place your ingredients, forcing you to get creative with chairs, boxes and other decorative items so that you can get to those hard-to-reach places!

Besides the preset difficulties and challenges, you can customize your experience, as a dashboard is at your disposal with every setting being adjustable: how tall you start, fast you shrink, how fast you run, how high you jump. You can determine how long each device takes to process ingredients, or whether their placement is randomized. You can change the quantity of recipes and, by extension, the quantity of ingredients. Are the bottles spillable or breakable? You can even affect things like gravity, or whether you can double jump!

☹ What bothered me ☹
You cannot call this a simulation. All the chemical ingredients are randomized: the name, the color, the shape of the bottle. I'm not complaining that the names are made up (there are no such things as ninjatium and jumbozium), but there's no consistency. If I break a bottle, it will be restored as a different color. If I mistakenly mixed a red ingredient with water, the reverter will give me a yellow ingredient and...green water? While total randomization should allow infinite replayability, I would've loved to have consistent recipes, perhaps many of which you would learn as you played through the game, memorizing which ingredient to mix to get a specific result. There could be an entire wiki dedicated to the game's dozens or hundreds of recipes!

Mistakes are actually hard to make. Unless you don't actually bother to read the recipe, you'll never make any. There could've been partial recipe forcing you to take a guess or try a thing or two. Perhaps a recipe clipboard only gave a numbered sequence without telling you what the ingredient was, or perhaps it was unsure if Ingredient A had to be mixed with Ingredient B or Ingredient C. But there is no point in experimenting, since a mistake always results in a mix called "?!?!?" which is unusable except for the reverter. What if the wrong ingredient in the microwave caused an explosion? The wrong code sequence created a colorful (but pretty opaque) fog in the lab? What if the wrong mix resulted in fumes causing all sorts of wacky effect? Alas, there is none of this.

My Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - "It's up to you."

I actually had some fun with this game! However, having completed the included challenges, I'm left to make my own fun with the custom scenarios, increasing the complexity of the game by adding more recipes and ingredients, or by altering the parameters of my character, and I'm yet to see just how much replayability I will have before I'm bored. Still, I found the concept different and original, even if it seems a whole lot like Inch by Inch, so it gets my recommendation!

—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

Évaluation publiée le 17 février 2023
Size matters is a puzzle game in which you play as a shrinking scientist who tries to find a cure before it's too late.

Gameplay

The gameplay is quite simple. There are some ingredients scattered around the lab and you need to combine them to get new ingredients or modify them using various lab tools. The room is also full with hints about right combinations. Once you have done all required combinations you get the cure and you win a map. Usually a run does not take longer than 10-15 mins.

Yeah, it doesn't sound very exciting, but it is. At least for a few times, then you could replay it a few more times on various modes, like low gravity, etc, or by adjusting various settings to create your own difficulty and complexity for your game.

Conclusion

Size Matters offers short session gameplays, but not much replayability, so you probably will end up with 1-2h playtime max(unless you are an achievement hunter, then 4-5h). When the game is heavily discounted, then that price is fine for this amount of expected gameplay and then also worth it just to experience it and have a few hours of fun with it.

Visuals: 6/10.
Atmosphere: 7/10.
Amount of crash: Not experienced any.
Bugs: Some claim it is a bug that you can’t crouch sometimes, but it happens only if you shrink under some heights, so I guess it is more like a planned feature.

Hey, I am an achievement hunter!

How to perfect?: Finish one run on each difficulty, mode and collect the misc achievements. Steam guide available.
Perfection Difficulty: 4/10. While you need to play at least once on harder preset difficulties too, the game is still easy.
100% time: 4-5h

If you like to earn achievements, but in enjoyable, fun and entertaining games, then please follow my Average Achievement Hunter curator or just check out our curated games if you looking for some gaming tips:-) Thanks

Évaluation publiée le 26 février 2023
As a scientist in real life, I really wanted to like this game, however, it was mostly a boring letdown.

The basic mechanics of the game involved mixing various chemicals together to create new chemicals to stop yourself from shrinking and go back to your normal size. The gameplay is intuitive and straightforward, making it easy to pick up and play. The game also requires patience and careful planning to succeed in your goal. This balance of accessibility and difficulty made the game engaging and enjoyable...for the first 2-3 hours...

My main issue with this game is that I felt aimless past the preset scenarios. There isn't much pushing you to play more once you beat the 6 preset scenarios. Sure, there is a custom mode, but it isn't much fun creating custom scenarios for yourself to beat. For me, it just doesn't feel the same as completing the preset scenarios. It is also useful for hunting some achievements, but I can't say I used it for anything else other than that.

Also, some actions are quite glitchy. There was even an instance where I did an action too quickly (the whole point of this game, essentially) and locked myself out of using a machine 12-minutes into the scenario, which forced me to restart the scenario when I was almost finished. Things like this reduce the fun that this game could have even more.

Overall, this is a fairly short game that gets pretty boring after spending a few hours on it. Sure, the core gameplay and mechanics are solid, but the boredom I felt within only 2-3 hours of gameplay makes it hard for me to recommend this game. I spent more hours feeling bored and trying to extract fun out of the game than I spent genuinely enjoying the experience. Since Steam doesn't have a mixed review option, I'll have to not recommend this game due to the prior factors.

Забавная игра на логику, где нужно в роли постоянно уменьшающегося лаборанта сделать противоуменьшающее зелье

"Дорогая, я уменьшил себя"
Не всегда попадается такая головоломка, где нужно решить некую задачу и при это рост персонажа постоянно уменьшается. Как следствие уменьшения персонажа, все объекты вокруг увеличиваются. Но формула увеличивающего зелья уже есть и нужно смешать нужные компоненты. Формулы разбросаны по всей лаборатории и компоненты с ничего не значащими названиями тоже в наличии. Нужно лишь точно их смешать и обрести долгожданные ключевые сыворотки, которые волшебным образом вернут незадачливого профессора в естесственный вид.

Другое дело, что вся игра по сути из этой механики и состоит - меняются лишь скорость уменьшения и положение объектов в лаборатории. Так что вещица немного рутинная, но если хочется новых ощущений и поглядеть постоянно увеличивающийся мир вокруг, то можно попробовать.

Плюсы
+ Необычная механика игры на логику в роли уменьшающегося профессора
+ Есть русский перевод
+ Игра хорошо оптимизирована
+ Есть облачное сохранения и достижения

Минусы
- Игра порой однообразна
- Элементы даже близко не напоминают реальные
- Управление несколько своеобразное, но можно приноровиться
- Графика порой слишком схематична

По итогу, если хочется немного разнообразить имеющиеся головоломки, то можно попробовать и эту игру. В игровом процессе ничего поражающего воображение нет, но всё же пару часов можно скоротать.
 
meetnik

Évaluation publiée le 9 aout 2022
先に言っておくと酔う。

このゲームは体が小さくなってしまう前に解毒薬を作るパズルゲーム。

実験室のいたる所に薬品と薬品の合成方法メモが置かれている。
それらを集めて解毒薬を作っていくが、時間とともに体が小さくなっていく。

体が小さくなると机の上のものが取れなかったり、机の上の装置の操作ができなくなったりする。時間が経つにつれて行動自由度が減るのを見据えて足場を用意しておくなど、作業の段取りを考えるのが一つの要素。

もともとの一人称視点がかなり酔いやすいが、身長が低くなって視点が下がるのも酔いを加速させていそう。


もう一つのメインのパズル要素が薬品合成の段取りだ。集めた情報で合成方法は多数判明するが、解毒薬に到達するまでにはいくつも段階がある。手持ちの薬品の名前から先にできる作業を素早く読み取って処理を開始する必要がある。

一度処理を始めると一定時間手が空くので、並行してできる作業を探したり次に処理する薬品を準備したりする。
慌てて薬品を操作するとひっくり返したり瓶が割れたりして時間をロスする。危険予測を忘れずに。


ゲーム全体は日本語化されているが、薬品は英語のままだ。
そもそも架空の薬品名なので英語が読める読めないの話ではないが、アルファベットの文字列に馴染みのない人には覚えづらいかもしれない。個人的にはこれもパズル要素の一つとして受け止めることができた。

また、科学の現場であれば日本でも英語で記載することが多そうなのでむしろ正しいのかもしれない


念のために言っておくと酔う。
 
rakuyou

Évaluation publiée le 17 octobre 2022
Ein kleines nettes Spiel gegen die Zeit. Und nein, der Titel ist witzig, hat aber nichts mit dem zu tun, an was viele Menschen wohl dabei denken.

Das Labor 
Une capture d'écran de Size Matters
Par : Keks

Worum geht es?

Wir spielen einen Chemiker, der durch einen Unfall zu schrumpfen beginnt. Ein Gegenmittel muss her, aber zackig. Die Zutaten kugeln alle irgendwo im Labor herum. Die Anleitungen sind ebenso verstreut, erklären uns dann aber, wie welche Chemikalie zu bearbeiten ist, um schlussendlich drei Schlüssel zu erstellen, die zusammengenommen das Gegenmittel erzeugen, das uns heilt.

Erschwert wird das ganze noch eben dadurch, dass wir schrumpfen und mit der Zeit nicht mehr so leicht an alles rankommen. Da muss man dann mit Kisten und Stühlen improvisieren, um auf Arbeitshöhe zu kommen.

Je nach eingestelltem Schwierigkeitsgrad ist die Zeit knapper, die Zutaten mehr und die Anzahl nötiger Schritte zur Rettung höher.

Es gibt noch ein paar andere Gags, wie geringe Schwerkraft oder dass man von Anfang an winzig ist. Für ganz Spaßige kann man auch benutzerdefiniert fast alles selbst einstellen.

Rätselhafte Chemie 
Une capture d'écran de Size Matters
Par : Keks

Macht es Spaß?

Ja. Für einige Zeit jedenfalls. Es ist ein kleines Hektikspiel und es kann eine Weile dauern, bis man routiniert alle Herausforderungen meistert. In jedem Durchgang sind die Objekte woanders versteckt und die Rezepte anders, so dass man es schon einige Male durchspielen mag.

Mischen von Chemikalien 
Une capture d'écran de Size Matters
Par : Keks

Technik

Es ist ein einfaches aber ausreichend gut gestaltetes Spiel. Mehr wäre unnötig.

Man steuert es mit Tastatur und Maus.

Sonstiges

Ein einzelner Durchgang mag kaum länger als 10 oder 15 Minuten dauern. Mit ein paar Fehlversuchen und verschiedenen Modi kann man aber doch ein paar Stunden damit verbringen. Dann hat man es aber wohl auch über.

Es gibt sehr viele Errungenschaften, die zu erhalten doch einige Zeit und teils auch schon sehr zügiges Arbeiten erfordert.

In Zahlen für mich persönlich ein Unterhaltungswert von 9/10.

Ein kleines Hektikspiel, überraschend unterhaltsam für eine Weile.

Also den reguläre Preis finde ich etwas hoch, aber im Rabatt bei momentan 2,24€ ist es OK.


Dies ist mein subjektiver Spieleindruck. Für meine Wertung zählt, wie gut es mich unterhalten hat. Entsprechend der Daumen nach oben oder unten, abhängig davon, ob ich es einem ähnlich gesinnten Spieler weiterempfehle. Der Spieleindruck eines anderen Spielers kann aber durchaus stark davon abweichen.
 
Keks

"Yeah Mr. White! Yeah Science!"
 
W MAN

Évaluation publiée le 16 septembre 2021
In Size Matters, the premise is that you are a scientist who has accidentally dumped shrinking formula on themselves in a lab accident. In practice, however, this is wholly irrelevant save for the “setting” of the areas.

The game is all about the mechanics. You start out large, but as the game goes on, you get progressively smaller and smaller. There are several pieces of lab equipment on benches around the lab, beakers of various chemicals, and notes – both written on the walls and on notepads – which contain instructions as to what chemicals you must combine, microwave, mix with water, or process through a machine that requires processing codes.

By the end of the level, you will have used every single chemical and formula in order to produce three chemical “keys”, which you load into one final device to make the cure and revert yourself to your original size.

If you take too long, you shrink to nothing and die.

Simple enough, right?

Yeah, actually, that’s about all there is to it.

The game is set in six 3D environments, most vaguely laboratory themed, though at least one level diverges from that somewhat. The game basically consists of two phases – you will want to start searching the lab immediately to find all the chemicals and the chemical formulas, and then you’ll want to start processing them through the lab equipment to create the keys.

All of the labs have numerous drawers, shelves, and various other places that can contain the various chemicals or lab notes. The chemicals mostly aren’t too difficult to find, but the lab notes that tell you what to do can not only be in drawers, but on top of high places, and can be easy to overlook.

This is a game with a time limit, and each round it varies somewhat. But the really tricky part – at least in theory – is that the longer a round goes on, the smaller you get. Initially, it’s pretty easy to access all of the lab equipment and chemicals and explore the lab, but as you get smaller and smaller, you not only slow down, but it becomes increasingly difficult to get up to the lab benches. If you get too small, you need to have stuff lying around on the floor to climb up on – and preferably, you set that up beforehand, when you were large, so it wouldn’t be too onerous to do, as you also get weaker and have more trouble moving things around as you get smaller.

The main problem is that, for all this, if you figure out how the game works, it honestly becomes a bit rote. You set up for yourself as you’re searching, and it never really involves piling up more than a couple things at most, and often just one; on some of the easier levels, you don’t even need to bother, as you can solve them fast enough to not need to worry too much about shrinking.

There are six preset levels, with various starting heights, rate of shrinkage, gravity, and the number of things you have to solve, which take place in five different environments. Strangely, there is a sixth environment which is used in absolutely none of the preset game setups for no apparent reason.

The game also allows you to completely customize your rate of shrink, your speed, gravity, the processing speed of various devices, and pretty much everything else relevant to the game physics.

In addition to the six preset levels, there’s a bunch of random achievements for doing various random things in the game – some of these you’ll acquire naturally, some you need to work at, some you need to search for. Amusingly, one of them is for failing a mission and dying – and it was the very last achievement I got, because this is not a particularly difficult game (though I did get down to the last 10 seconds on a 25 minute mission once).

All in all, this is an extremely simplistic game. It took me under two hours to beat all the presets, and about four to get all the achievements and 100% the game. It doesn’t really have a ton of gameplay variety on offer, and while having six different environments is nice, they aren’t really all that distinctive in terms of gameplay – in the end, you are doing the same things, just with a different room setup.

There’s not a whole lot to this game.

I got it as part of a Humble Bundle, and there, it wasn’t really “unreasonable” as a throwaway game – something that seems kind of neat, that you tinker with briefly and then never play again.

But as a stand-alone title, it is kind of hard for me to recommend it. It just feels so ephemeral; there’s really just not a whole lot to it, and it doesn’t really do anything particularly clever with the shrinking.

They had an idea, they built a simple game around it… and while it is okay, it is just nothing really to write home about. I can’t really recommend it to anyone, even though it isn’t really bad, because it isn’t really all that good, either. It simply is.
 
excal

Évaluation publiée le 8 mai 2021
This is more of a toybox than a game. Yes, there is a win/fail condition but the basic setup and mechanics have no framework to rest on. A short "campaign" of sorts where the player is guided through the different laboratories and more difficulty options are tweaked I think would have helped. As it is the onus is mostly on the player to experiment with the different settings and find the easter eggs, so it kind of ends up being one of those "make your own fun" things which is why I said it is more of a toybox than a game. It is fun, in the same way that something like Viscera Cleanup Simulator is fun, just in a much smaller, less time consuming package.

Is it worth playing if you have the chance? Absolutely; it's quite enjoyable. Do I recommend it at $10? Considering average playtime seems to be about 1-2h, I would say wait for a sale unless that value proposition works out for you.

Évaluation publiée le 17 février 2020
Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

Size Matters had 2 laboratory to play in. You have many options to change the game difficulty.

Search ingredients and formulas to combine the ingredients until you find the ultimate cure to get back to your normal size.

The game is fun and pretty challenging.

Évaluation publiée le 4 juin 2021
Size Matters is a short, but fun game. Unfortunately, the replayability is rather low, because the concept remains always the same.

The game is quite simple: You are in a laboratory and you are shrinking. You are therefore forced to find formulas and chemicals, to combine them, microwave them, etc. This will help you mixing 3 keys, that will allow you to produce the antidote. The longer you take, the tinier you become. If you are really slow, you must jump on different obstacles to keep producing your mixture. But this didn’t happen to me. The game is so simple, that it is rather hard to shrink that much, that it gets difficult to reach the different objects/machines.

There are 6 predesigned levels with different difficulties, but you can also make custom settings. Also there are 6 maps in total. That’s a solid number.

Honestly, the game is very fun. But due to the fact, that it is always the same gameplay, I won’t keep playing this. I finished all custom levels in about an hour. It is a quite short game.

The graphics are fine, and the soundtrack is okay (but it gets annoying if you play for too long).

Great game, innovative concept, fun for a couple of hours.

Évaluation publiée le 1 juin 2021
Aus Groß wird Klein

Es kommt eben doch auf die Größe an. – That`s what she said ;-/

Gameplay
In “Size Matters” arbeiten wir im Labor und müssen ein Gegenmittel herstellen. Denn wir schrumpfen mit der Zeit immer mehr und müssen uns beeilen, zunächst alle Informationen und Reagezien zu finden und anschließend zu bearbeiten. Dabei mischen wir neue Dinge zusammen, müssen mit Codes arbeiten oder etwas plump in der Mikrowelle erhitzen. Dadurch entstehen wiederum neue Stoffe, die wir schlussendlich zu 3 Schlüsseln verarbeiten, die unser Schrumpfen beenden. Das Problem liegt auf der Hand: Umso länger wir brauchen, umso mehr entwickelt sich „Size Matters“ zu einem Jump `n` Run, da wir immer schwieriger an die Mittel und die Geräte herankommen.
Als kleiner Kerl müssen wir uns schon überlegen, wie wir ein wenig Struktur in die Bude bringen wollen 
Une capture d'écran de Size Matters
Par : Drakezer0

Die Schwierigskeitgrade bleiben da aber eher entspannt und eine Runde dauert durchschnittlich vielleicht 10-15 Minuten. Ein besonderes Feature ist dabei, dass man sich seine Runde sehr genau einstellen und sich so seine Herausforderung selber bauen kann. Trotzdem hat man nach ca. 2 Stunden nahezu Alles vom Spiel gesehen und kann nur noch überlegen, sich jetzt mal eine richtige Herausforderung selber zu stellen. Erwähnenswert ist vielleicht noch, dass mir ein Bug passiert ist, der einmal die Runde für mich unspielbar gemacht hat. Aber wie gesagt, nur einmal!

Story
Es gibt keine Kampagne oder Geschichte. Aber wer irgendwie an Doc Brown aus Zurück in die Zukunft[de.wikipedia.org] und gleichzeitig an Liebling, ich habe die Kinder geschrumpft[de.wikipedia.org] gedacht hat, der hebe an dieser Stelle bitte die Hand.

Grafik/Sound
„Size Matters“ verwendet eine simple 3D Grafik, die mich an eine Simulation erinnert. Ansonsten sehen wir halt…Labore. Wobei die Karte mit dem Wohnzimmer schon ganz nett aussah. Wichtig waren halt viele kleine Gegenstände, die man sich als Kletterhilfe ranholen kann.
Size Matters 
Une capture d'écran de Size Matters
Par : Drakezer0

Soundtechnisch gibt es leider nur zwei wirkliche Soundtracks im Spiel. Einmal im Menü und einmal auf der Karte. Aber sie gehen dafür ganz gut ins Ohr.

Fazit
Kann ich „Size Matters“ jetzt weiterempfehlen? Grundsätzlich definitiv! Es ist eine witzige Idee und macht wirklich Spaß. Ein paar Stunden kann man im Spiel verbringen und die Unterhaltung ist für einen Abend gerettet. Aber der derzeitige Preis von 9€ ist etwas hoch für diese kurzfristige Unterhaltung. Ich selber habe es als Beiwerk in einem Humble Bundle bekommen und würde sonst zum Kauf im Angebot raten.

Eine witzige Idee für dieses Review wäre es gewesen, die Schriftgröße immer weiter zu verkleinern. Aber das wäre dann vielleicht doch zu klein geworden. Übrigens: Für mehr Reviews kannst du meiner Steamgruppe folgen.

For other game reviews, please follow us at What The Game?

This game left me feeling like I had just participated in a new installment of Honey I Shrunk the Kids, however we shrunk ourselves! Size Matters is a fast paced puzzle game about the player being a scientist, whom is scrambling in their lab to reverse a chemical reaction that has you constantly shrinking. Initially, you may be thinking that it doesn't sound like a twist that would have you in a panic, but you'd be wrong.

Although, there are sliders to adjust the challenge to your liking in several different way, which is a fantastic way of adding in more replay value, you also do have what I feel are the intended difficulties that are easy, medium and hard. With easy, I did find it pretty easy, but it was a great tutorial type experience. Normal had me worried I may not make it and hard mode had me outright failing.

Your goal to not shrink has you frantically searching the lab for base chemicals and little clipboards with clues. Not only that, but there are clues written on the whiteboards and things of this nature as well, so you have to be very clear with things in your environment to reference to. Once you have gathered your clues, you have to start figuring out where to start. At this point you're probably already noticing a difference in your eye level and the panic begins as you try to craft the formula to save yourself.

Size Matters really does take a very interesting concept and bring it to life. Using your brain will be a must in this puzzle game, so if that's how you like your puzzles then jump into the fun. This title is a for sure buy in my book and I will be suggesting this to all of my friends. Very well done game here. This is the type of game I really hope to see DLC for.

Évaluation publiée le 11 janvier 2022
#Beat all scenarios plus a custom game
Around 4 hours

Size matters is a fairly unique game. Here is the pitch: You go into a lab. You are shrinking constantly. You have to make an antidote to stop the shrinking. Lucky for you, everything you need is in the room. Unlucky for you, all those things are everywhere and the recipe for the antidote changes every time you play. You need 3 key (chemicals) to win.

Loop:
- Find all chemicals (these all have fake names. You can also insert your own)
- Find all chemical combinations / recipies
- Use the "science equipment" to mix these and create a cure

- You are constantly battling getting smaller.
- You most certainly come up with a methodology pretty quickly

A fun game with some replayability if you want to keep going after the pre-determined scenarios. There are a LOT of customization options. Recommended!

Principe vraiment sympa mais pas exploité à fond.

On doit créer un antidote, on a des solutions chimiques de base et des formules cachées un peu partout dans le labo ( tiroir, placard etc. ) et hop on est parti pour faire son petit chimiste le plus rapidement possible.

Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2021
关注斗鱼游戏社区，随时了解主播推荐的好游戏。
访问斗鱼鱼吧社区参与互动，活动好礼送不停！

《Size Matter》是一款化学实验模拟游戏，在这个游戏中玩家将扮演一位科学家，因为摄入了某种未知的化学物质导致身体无时无刻不在变小。随着身体的逐渐缩小，在实验室内的移动就变得越来越棘手。为了到达设备和原料所在地，玩家不得不面对由杂乱实验室构成的跳跃迷宫。借助设备与材料，在身体完全变小之前根据配方步骤制作出解药。但千万要记住，时间就是生命，若是身体变得太小那就只能gg。整体上是一款节奏较快的“逃脱”类游戏这应该也算是逃脱吧，逃脱变小hhh，因为有着时间的限制有着一定的难度，玩起来会较为手忙脚乱。

游玩体验

玩起来并没有想象中的那么妙趣横生，甚至可以说到后期有些枯燥。到了中后期的流程可以说和前期的体验完全就是翻版，无非是多了些步骤和设备以及时间变得更短以增加难度，但并没有同时引入新的内容而导致审美疲劳无法继续吸引玩家，使得游玩体验的乐趣大大降低。

虽说中后期的体验因为重复度导致体验不佳，但前期的流程还是挺有新意的。解毒剂的制造分为三个步骤：寻找成分以及配方、化合物的组合与合成和最后的制得解药。首先需要搜寻实验室，寻找制作解药的原料和配方，配方一般来说都由三种关键成分组成；在找到所需的配方以及原料之后，使用化学处理器可将两种不同的成分合成一种全新的化合物，使用代码组合器通过输入对应的配方代码可将某一种化合物转换成另一种对应的不同化合物，至于微波炉和还原器，这两种设备可以在制作失败的情况下回收原材料。这一个整个过程看起来很有趣，玩起来其实并没有想象中的那么好玩，玩起来反而觉得有些硬核。好玩的部分我觉得更多的是前期找解药的原料和配方的过程，在迷宫一样的实验室中冒险。

游戏有中文，但不少配方不知道是为了保留原汁原味的配方还是遗漏翻译的问题，有一部分的文本还是英文，有漏翻情况。而且游戏引导并不好，很大一部分的内容基本上都靠玩家自己探索。同时配方数量并不多，翻来覆去也就那么几个，并且制作失败的特效也几乎没有，希望这些在后续的版本更新中能够丰富。

总结

有些硬核的化学实验模拟游戏，前期游戏体验很有趣，但由于内容不足以及重复度较高的问题，游戏中后期的趣味性并不高。同时还有些漏翻译等小问题。整体上还值得一玩，希望能够继续丰富游戏内容以提升后期游戏体验的趣味性。

游玩百态，将游玩心得用汉语化作玩家的指明灯，(๑•̀ㅂ•́)و✧

Évaluation publiée le 3 aout 2021
I really hate giving negative reviews. I rarely ever do it. I feel like I should for this game though because there is so much wrong here that it's impossible for the development team to have seen this, and not noticed these things.

The game is not done. The bugs are plentiful. The low gravity mode is so buggy that some may find it completely unplayable. There's issues that persists across all the modes like flasks spawning inside of objects making them impossible to grab, physics being so buggy that things just go flying, collision being so off that stuff simply doesn't make sense. Physics are a big part of this game, but it's so buggy that the physics are also one of the game's biggest hindrances. Many of the bugs happen BECAUSE of the physics. What a mess..

So, that's what this all comes down to really.. the bugs . There are just too many. I play lots of buggy games but this is too much for me. I will say, I did enjoy some of what I played.. But I know I will not touch this game again until it gets a bug fixing update. I can not recommend this game in it's current state. If these issues are fixed and the game is polished up, this review will be changed accordingly.

Best of luck to the Mazen team.

Цель - быстренько склепать противоядие. Для этого у нас есть несколько аппаратов для смешивания реагентов и всякого такого.

Сложность невысокая, в самый раз быстренько пройти, не успевает надоесть.

В общем, ставлю лукас.

Produit reçu gratuitement

Size Matters is a pretty cool puzzle game where you race against time to find an antidote to stop yourself from shrinking before it's too late.

You search for base chemicals and modify them using the formulas written on hidden notes and scrawled on the walls and chalkboard. To modify chemicals, you can use equipment available such as the microwave, combiner, etc. All the equipment take a considerable amount of time so planning ahead to minimize the time lost is a key part of the strategy.

As time progresses and you shrink to a certain height, and you have to use objects around you such as chairs, boxes, etc. to create makeshift ramps and jumping points so you can make your way back to the counter tops that hold the equipment needed. It creates a sense of urgency and another layer of strategy required to make sure you create the antidote in time.

Overall, Size Matters is a neat puzzle game. It's pretty unique, and you can tweak a lot of the settings to make it easier or much harder or even just make it very silly.

Produit reçu gratuitement

Size Matters让理科生的我怀念起了校园时代在实验室的日子，在枯燥但不乏味的实验室中与时间赛跑，努力配置解药。
疯狂模式，在有限的提示下从失败中摸索正确的配方，就像是侦探游戏寻找线索层层推理最终得出正确答案，令人着迷。试剂没有中文而且是学名这阻挡了我探索的脚步，无法理解合成前后的含义只能凭借硬性记忆，如果有化学方程式就算没有汉化也能大致理解其中的含义。
在游戏中试剂会随着高度和拿起时有没有障碍物会出现试剂洒出甚至瓶子破碎，这非常好。如果你喜欢解密和探索的过程，那么这款游戏会非常适合你。
游戏中遇到的问题：
1、拖动瓶子进入试验台按E时出现过两次不明原因白屏画面消失，只有左上角显示。
2、拿着配方或试剂瓶的时候方向键不移动视角向下会自动向后移动
3、药水调和台已经放入一瓶药水的情况下不拿出，鼠标单击它会从实验室消失，放入新的药水组合将暂
时无法合成
4、微波炉里有药水正在加热的情况下，再次放入其他药水鼠标单击此药水它会从实验室消失，微波炉里
的药水加热后可以正常取出
5、困难默认模式下在7-8分钟左右遇到一次试剂放进微波炉加热变成解药原料没有名字的问题，并且无
法放进解药原料中，而且不能还原,且第二种解药的原料只差最后一步
5、人物和建筑物模型问题，距离试验台很近的时候跳越会顶住人物模型，手持试剂跳箱子也会遇到这个
问题；抽屉里的配方取出时有时会卡住只能关上抽屉等它掉出来，配方在高于人物的地方跳跃拿出时配
方会卡在半空
只需要注意这些操作避免碰到类似的问题，就不会影响正常游戏。
祝你们游戏愉快，并再次感谢我的朋友。

Évaluation publiée le 21 novembre 2019
Produit reçu gratuitement

Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé

The main concept of Size Matters puts you in the shoes like some kinda mad Scientist dashing around a lab attempting to use different pieces of apparatus on ingredients to process, code, revert, restore, pour, microwave all to find the Antidote to stop you shrinking!!!

To help you along, you search for ingredients & information Notepads scattered about the lab. Each Notepad has a formula of some kind written upon it. Putting all this together plus wall board notes creates a chain of actions needed to be performed. Its then a process of elimination which you can follow up to a point until you arrive at the last prefinal ingredients. These prefinal ingredients conclude you to create the final Key ingredients 1, 2 & 3. You then put them into the Antidote Producer to produce the Antidote - grow to normal size & complete the game within the chosen time frame...... Got all tha? Good. Straight forward, simple, huh? ..... WRONG!!!!

The Ingredients:
With a cosmetic variety of colour & flask shapes implemented adds a good science look & feel to the game. Some can be visible & others are hiding, find them!! Your going to come across some looooong fabricated sciencyyy ingredient names too. Which is ironic cus the Periodic Table of Elements is displayed on a wall!!! LOL. Oh, & don't be surprised to see names you maybe familiar with! Tip: Grouping them together provides quicker checking & selection. Holding distance is controlled by with the mouse wheel.

Notepads/Wall Boards:
The heart of the games drive. These contain the crucial information you need to act upon. Notepads can easily be unnoticed on shelves cus there flat &, dependant upon the amount available, two can be found in one draw. Notepads are easily readable while holding cus there wordings upright & distance is controlled by with the mouse wheel. Tip: Standing them against things & walls allows quick distant reading.

The Apparatus:
Note: Make sure you stand close enough to each piece of equipment so that it is outlined white indicating its interactable. All Apparatus time durations are selectable.

The Microwave.
Is used to convert a single ingredient into another usable one. (*)

Chemical Processor.
This device Is used to combine any two ingredients into one single ingredient. (*)

Code Combiner.
Converts ingredients into another after entering a code key which can be input using the KP. (*)

The Restorer.
Now be careful.... Checking the Breakable Flasks option & setting the Breakforce level at 3 in the Play menu adds a more realistic approach by allowing flasks to smash when dropped!! I recommend playing with these settings. When this occurs the smashed flasks ingredient name(s) appear in The Restorers menu. Selecting a name instructs the device to restore that ingredients Flask.

Antidote Producer.
Once you've discovered all three Key ingredients insert them into this machine to produce your Antidote. You will then become normal size & the game ends with a small stat review.

(*) Indicates a failed ingredient attempt procedure occured labeled '????'. (See Reverter)

The Reverter.
This apparatus fully reverts any ingredient to its original flasked state. PHEW!!!

Play Menu
The settings here are the very heart of Size Matters. With sooooo many things to tweak you can create a session as easy or hard, simple or complex has you prefer so that each game can have diversity, challenge & variety. Almost everything is optionable: Movement speed, Height starting/ending, Jump height, Double mid air jump times, etc. Including shrinking time - sixty minutes maximum. To reset back to default settings, click Normal. For greater depth & challenge many options are randomizable. Even the Apparatus time durations are changeable. All of this will pit you against wits & quick decisive thinking when playing a timed game. Did I say timed game? Oh yes, butthere is a way you can pause shrinking.This can give you a relaxed, take your time long complex session if all you want to be is just the creative experimental Scientist. More is planned to follow....

Wrapping up:
Mazen Games's Size Matters was influenced by a previous similar game. They flasked a game plus there own ideas then put both Flasks into a Chemical Processor & produced Size Matters. The results of which created another levelled more compelling more accomplished game about science & intrigue. Complexity & diversity assured. This one aspect alone puts Size Matters in its own class & sets the standard for future games in this new genre to follow.

10/10.

What is Size Matters ?

I love when I discover something unique like this, what a nice and interesting concept for a game, here you play as a scientist who is shrinking as time passes and your objective is to find the formula that will reverse that effect in order to do that you have to run against the time finding the clues which are scattered around your laboratory and use different tools to combine elements in order to make the parts of the antidote, here we see a simple altho unique concept execute in such a fine way that makes it so easy to get into and yet so fun and challenging at the same time, its addictive, the best thing is that its also has multiple options to personalize how each level will be played, you can toggle a lot of things to make it easier or difficult before you start a level, its a very replayable game that will entertain you for some hours, also its a very cheap game too, so Im giving this a recommendation, a truly well deserved one.

Évaluation publiée le 15 aout 2021
As a disclaimer I received this game as part of Humble Choice. It certainly wouldn't have crossed my path otherwise but I am glad it did.

Mechanically very sound and takes a little while to get used to. However, once you have worked out what is happening, the gameplay is all much of a muchness. However, that muchness is really quite fun and good for short bursts of fun.

There's not a huge amount of content here, and I've managed to zip through it all in just under four and a half hours, with all achievements. However, this is procedurally generated, so if you're the type of person who isn't bothered about "progression" per se, this could have a fair amount of replay value (although I would like to see additional machines and potential in future to increase the run time).

All in all, game is a lot of fun, but perhaps a little bare bones for someone with a completion itch like me. If you're looking for quick bursts of mix and match fun, this is your game.

Alles in allem ein gut gelungenes Spiel für zwischendurch.

Évaluation publiée le 11 mai 2021
I played 100% of the content available at time of review
- This game is well put together and doesn't have any bugs that I could tell.
- The 'campaign' 'puzzles' are very simple and not that difficult (I didn't lose once). Those are in air quotes because the campaign is just 6 scenarios and the puzzles are just combos. An example: (A + B = C), (D + E = F), C + F = Key. Creating those combos is either two letters or a letter plus a number. That's it, that's the extent of the puzzle aspect. To make that a little bit challenging (and only slightly) you get a time limit of your player character slowly shrinking...which barely affects the gameplay.
- This game severely lacks content and plays like an early access title, its saving grace is that is priced cheap. I got this through the humble bundle but its only worth around $2 on an 80% sale.

I'm recommending as it is kinda fun to burn a couple hours in but overall there are better games to spend time and money on. The dev needs to spend a lot of time adding content to this game or its just not worth it.

4 out of 10.

Évaluation publiée le 28 mai 2022
Size Matters

Symulator małego naukowca. Relaksująca i bardzo miła gra. Soundtrack spokojny i miły dla ucha nawet długo słuchany, pasuję do gry idealnie. Grafika dobra i bardzo prosta, aczkolwiek jest ona ładna. Efekty są słabe, ale nie zwraca się na nie uwagi. W grze mamy 6 laboratoriów. Mapy są ładne i dobrze wykonane. Prawie wszystko, jak nie wszystko, można podnieść. W grze mamy również 57 osiągnięć, są one sensowne i miło się je robi. Aby zdobyć wszystkie osiągnięcia, trzeba poświęcić około 8-10 godzin. Mamy kilka trybów gry, między innymi tryb niskiej grawitacji. Można też grać na własnych ustawieniach. Gameplay jest bardzo prosty i niewymagający, ale za to dostarcza dużo frajdy i relaksuje. Jedynymi minusami jest powtarzalność i długość gry.

Fabuła | Cel

Celem gry jest odnalezienie wszystkich przepisów i składników oraz zrobienie 3 kluczy, z których robi się antidotum. Mamy wyznaczony czas, od 1 minuty do 60 minut.

Minusy

Jak już wcześniej pisałem gra ma dwa minusy. Pierwszym minusem jest długość gry. Gra jest bardzo krótka i jak się zrobi wszystkie osiągnięcia, to nie ma już nic do roboty. Drugim minusem jest powtarzalność. Za każdym razem robisz to samo, różni się jedynie przepisami, nazwami składników oraz laboratorium. Rozgrywka sama w sobie jest taka sama za każdym razem, no może, że gra się na innych trybach, między innymi niskiej grawitacji, wtedy jest jako tako odmienność jednak różni się tym, że jest tylko ciężej.

Podsumowanie

Warta zakupu gra, szczególnie że jest bardzo tania, klucz można kupić za kilka złotych. Jak już wcześniej pisałem, gra jest prosta, ale naprawdę miła w rozgrywce. Mogę śmiało polecić wszystkim kupić tę grę.

5.5/10

Non recommandé
2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 juin 2021
Size Matters is an interesting idea with a below average execution.

The actual game play is pretty simple, you'll spend half your time looking for ingredients/recipes and the other half waiting for progress bars to fill up. It's mildly fun, but the core game play isn't improved by the shrinking mechanic.

For this game to really shine the rooms should be designed so navigation during a variety of player heights is possible. Instead to navigate at smaller sizes you either need to plan ahead and move some chairs and boxes around or die. Generally planning ahead isn't worth it, because you're better off just looking for more recipes and getting more progress bars cooking, so I mostly ignored the shrinking mechanic and just played find the recipes...

2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 septembre 2021
This is a very fun and unique experience. It starts out pretty easy, but it gradually becomes trickier the smaller you get. Eventually, you need to put stuff in front of the tables to climb on, but because moving stuff around also gets harder, you have to plan ahead.
The game's difficulty is incredibly customizable as there's a slider for pretty much every aspect of the game, but there are a few presets as well of course. You can even have some fun entering custom names for the chemicals.
The game is easy to pick up and it does not take long to understand the basics. Unfortunately, there's no campaign mode or anything like that, so the game becomes repetitive rather quickly. Definitely worth checking out, but don't expect to be hooked for more than a few hours.

I also think this game might work very well in VR, but that's unfortunately not supported at the time of writing.

Évaluation publiée le 13 mars 2021
-----ENG-----
Size matters is a simulation game in which we will find ourselves in the role of a chemist who has started to shrink due to the ingestion of a chemical substance, in a race against time during which we should create the antidote to put an end to our condition.

The creation of the antidote is divided into three phases: search for ingredients and recipes, combination of compounds and final creation of the antidote.

During the game we will use tools to transform our ingredients: the chemical processor allows us to combine two ingredients to create a compound, the code combiner transforms one compound into another by entering a code, the microwave is ... a microwave and the reverter allows us to recover the ingredients in case we make a mistake.

Our shrinking will make it increasingly difficult for us to move around the map, so we will have to create routes using the various objects in the map, a feature that makes the gameplay very dynamic.

The game features many maps, all of which are very beautiful, and the larger maps will test our patience as we find more and more ingredients and recipes.

The game also has a good localization in Italian that has a few noteworthy errors but which do not affect the gaming experience.

Size Matters is a fun and brilliant game, which I recommend to anyone who is passionate about time trials and chemistry.

-----IT-----
Size matters è un gioco simulativo nel quale ci ritroveremo nei panni di un chimico che ha iniziato a rimpicciolire a causa dell'ingerimento di una sostanza chimica, in una corsa contro il tempo durante la quale dovremmo creare l'antidoto per porre fine alla nostra condizione.

La creazione dell'antidoto si divide in tre fasi: ricerca di ingredienti e ricette, combinazione dei composti e creazione finale dell'antidoto.

Durante la partita utilizzeremo degli strumenti per traformare i nostri ingredienti: il processore chimico ci consente di unire due ingredienti per creare un composto, il combinatore di codici trasforma un composto in un altro tramite l'inserimento un codice, il microonde è... un microonde e il reverter ci perette di recuperare gli ingredienti in caso dovessimo aver commesso un errore.

Il nostro rimpicciolire ci renderà sempre più difficile spostarci nella mappa, per questo dovremo creare dei percorsi utilizzando i vari oggetti nella mappa, caratteristica che rende il gameplay molto dinamico.

Il gioco presenta molte mappe, tutte molto belle e le mappe più grandi metteranno a dura prova la nostra pazienza nel trovare un numero sempre maggiore di ingredienti e ricette.

Il gioco presenta anche una valida localizzazione in italiano che presenta pochi errori degni di nota ma che inficiano sull'esperienza di gioco.

Per concludere, Size Matters è un gioco divertente e geniale, che consiglio a tutti coloro che sono appassionati di prove contro il tempo e di chimica.

Évaluation publiée le 11 mai 2021
This game is currently in the Humble Bundle for May 2021. If you are interested in the game and it's before June 1st, 2021, consider picking up the game as part of the current monthly bundle.

I dislike games that forget to tell players the goal or give them a purpose. Size Matters focuses on a scientist who has accidentally created a potion that will make him shrink over time, and must create the antidote before he shrinks too small. That’s what I’ve learned from the description and gameplay at least. It’s an interesting concept but poor execution.

Much of Size Matters is about running around and finding ingredients and recipes, then following those instructions to create the antidote, and that’s it. After you solve a level, you’ll repeat the process in different rooms and slightly different situations. The idea of a shrinking player could have been more interesting, but mostly it’s just about restricting access to some areas, and if planned out, players can ensure they won’t have problems reaching what they have to find.

The big problem is there’s nothing that makes it exciting. It feels like a streamer game as you can name the elements after anyone you want. Putting Bucky in the microwave for my review? Oh no. It’s entertaining to laugh about as someone plays, but there’s very little purpose to play it more than a few times. After an hour I was starting to enjoy the concept, but it also felt like I saw everything the game had to offer.

Pick this up if you want a great concept that doesn’t stick around too long. But in reality, there’s probably a better version of the game somewhere, because this didn’t hold my attention. There are also some bugs like getting stuck in the tutorial part of the game which was annoying.

If you enjoyed this review or want to know what I think of other games in the bundle, check out the full review on or subscribe to my youtube channel:

Produit reçu gratuitement

What a tremendously unique gameplay experience!


OVERVIEW
In short...You drink something you really should not have + now you are shrinking!

You're in the lab, so all all you need to do is mix the elaborately named chemicals in the correct order to create an antidote...So simple any idiot could do it....BUT as you shrink you also get weaker! So lifting and moving the flasks and boxes in the lab becomes harder and harder to do!

It's a very funny, confusing yet simple game with an impressive number of modifiers to make the game much easier or much harder; Like having breakable beakers!


Points of Interest
I found the blur effect was horrid and I def. should have turned it off at the start.

The FPS is certainly an area which could use some serious attention.


Final Thoughts + Gameplay
The gameplay experience is already great with a decent selection of levels to pick from & updates keep improving the gameplay experience too!

(You can now cross off combinations on the clipboards).

3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 mars 2022
To be honest, I had my doubts about this game to begin with. I put off playing it for quite awhile, but finally decided to give it a shot. My fears and doubts were quickly confirmed, essentially for two reasons. First and foremost is the time element, "Size Matters." The game in and of itself is passingly interesting and challenging. However, as you progress in difficulty, your time AND your physical height becomes shorter and shorter while you have more and more to do. The chemicals, formulas, and tasks to perform all become increasingly complicated to the point of disbelief. It would be hard enough to do if your shrinking size wasn't an issue, but it boils down to the one and only issue in the game. Once you've decreased to a diminished height, there is quite literally nothing you can do. You can only compensate so much for your decrease in height and becomes the entire process soon becomes pointless. It becomes increasingly frustrating and, if and when you complete a level, there is absolutely no more reward than when you complete the simplest level. Once again, it becomes pointless. Second, the controls are VERY unforgiving. You have to operate the devices with exacting precision or they won't function at all. The microwave is particularly frustrating. You're rushing around like the proverbial chicken with its head cut off and when you simply can't get a necessary machine to work through no fault of your own, it becomes infuriating. What...is....the.....point! A game is supposed to 1/ be fun 2/ be challenging 3/ functional within a reasonable degree. It seems that the game makers just wanted to make a game that became utterly impossible, infuriatingly frustrating, all in the shortest time possible, while they sit back with your money, laugh, and mutter to themselves, "Stupid suckers. They'll buy anything."

Évaluation publiée le 25 avril 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

Ein spaßiges Gelegenheitsspiel für ein zwei Runden, welches dennoch den Grips fordert, wenn man es denn möchte. Worum es geht: Wir sind in unserem Labor und ein Experiment geht schief, die Nebenwirkung? wir schrumpfen! Um diesen Prozess aufzuhalten, müssen wir das Gegenmittel herstellen. Mischen, erwärmen und verändern. Der Ablauf ist an sich immer der selbe, dennoch können wir uns durch verschiedene Modi und Level spielen. Von super entspannt und mit Hilfen, wie Überschriften auf den Chemikalien, bis hin zum super stressigen Adrenalin Kick. Dabei sind die Runden immer neu aufgebaut, die Anleitungen und Co liegen wo anders, die Flaschen sehen mal anders aus, können zerbrechen, etc. etc. es gibt wirklich genug Auswahl. Der Stil lässt uns in eine kleine bunte Comic Welt fallen und die Musik unterstreicht die jeweiligen Situationen. Alles in allem ein gutes Spiel für ein paar Runden und für immer mal wieder zwischendurch :)

Évaluation publiée le 12 mai 2021
A fun, unique experience, albeit with a limited shelf life

Pros
-Has a reasonable tutorial, which is getting ever more rare these days
-Multiple difficulties / mods available from the get go, or you can just concoct your own through a million sliders
-Core gameplay loop is easy to pick up and gets more fun as you hit higher difficulty levels instead of getting more annoying

♥♥♥♥
-Lack of a campaign to keep you going
-Limited shelf life due to above paired with being a single player only title

Size Matters offers a fun, unique single player experience that mostly reminded me of Keep Talking And Nobody Explodes, if you’re familiar with that title. It offers a couple hours of joyful fake science and escape from everyday stress in the form of bogus virtual stress roughly 10-15 minutes at a time. As long as you come in knowing what to expect it’s a great game to pick up .

For more detail on the above points and a look at gameplay, please join me as I elaborate on my thoughts in this video:
Click Me .

Évaluation publiée le 20 juin 2022
Bought for $1.29 on Fanatical, and what a deal that was! Had a lot of fun in this, played it for 5.3h to complete it as much as I wanted to (see about Achievements later)

You play as a scientist who is SHRINKING! So it's a race against time. Not only is this significant as a time limit, but as you get smaller, it's harder to get around, you can't reach things, you can't jump as high, you're not strong enough to move things! You can build "staircases" but that eats up more of your time!

You have to find recipes (X + Y = Z) on clipboards or whiteboards, and find all the chemicals (with nonsense names). You can also get water from the sink. They might be out in the open, or in a drawer/cabinet, or placed way up high atop shelves etc

Once you've collected them all, your goal is to build an antidote for yourself, and then there are several things you must do with the chemicals to accomplish this:
-combine 2 together
-microwave them
-modify them in a machine with a 4 digit code
After doing a (could be LONG) series of those, you eventually end up with a "key" and you need to make 3 keys to get the antidote to your shrinking problem and win the stage!

There are ~5 different challenges programmed in (beginner through crazy) with locked-in specs like how tall/strong you start, how fast you shrink, time limit, etc. Crazy difficulty was CRAZY difficult indeed, but I got it, and it was fun!

Separately from those preprogrammed challenges, you can fully customize the experience. I had a good lot of fun with a long time limit and slow shrinking (so there's not a time crunch) but TONS of chemical messing about to finally reach the end. I think there were 24 recipe clipboards!

There are 6 different labs you can play in, and not all are used in the preprogrammed challenges, so make sure to check 'em out. I preferred the ones with lots of space to lay out all your clipboards and chemicals together.

I got all the achievements I wanted, which is almost all of them. I had to reference a few of 'em for collectibles and oddball ones. The ones I didn't want, you earn for "messing up" and needing to revert a mixture, or restore a broken item.

Good game, worth the $10 Steam price, check it out!
 
!Supreme Grand Wizard Yoodiv

The concept of the game is pretty simple - you are a scientist that shrinks, and you need to create an antidote to not die from shrinking by mixing various chemicals that you need to find around the lab. Sadly, this is more than a sandbox/proof-of-concept than a game. It's get boring pretty quickly, once you've played the tutorial, the rest of the game will be similar. Also, the more you shrink, the more clunky the experience becomes, like you can't even properly lift a notepad with a formula, really?
The only positive about this game is that it's quick and easy 100% achievements.

Évaluation publiée le 17 avril 2022
Видео обзор тут
Vidéo YouTube™: Создаём лекарство от уменьшения | Size matters | Обзор 
Vues : 40
Всем привет и добро пожаловать на канал о симуляторах😊 B cегодня для вас обзор на Size matter - головоломательный симулятор работы в хим.


Size matter - головоломательный симулятор работы в хим.лаборатории и не только,
где вам предстоит смешивать различные химикаты, пока не стало слишком поздно, для вас.

Итак, игра предложит вам несколько уровней сложности от легкой до сумасшедшей.
Каждой сложности соответствует своя лаборатория, но вы всегда можете поставить свои настройки и подстроить сложность и место как захотите.
Параметров для настройки достаточно, так что сможете испытать себя по полной.
А так же есть условия низкой гравитации и вариант если бы ваш рост изначально был на уровне дивана.

Так, пройдя несложное обучение, кстати, советую его пройти, чтобы сразу понять, как все работает и не тупить.
Вы начнете свое первое испытание.

Принцип игры на первый взгляд довольно простой, но все упирается в время, которое дается на выполнение задания.
А именно, с каждой секундой ваш рост уменьшается. Скажу честно по началу я сразу и не понял, почему всё стало выше.
А чтобы спасти себя от такой напасти, вам необходимо создать лекарство.

Оно в свою очередь делается из разных компонентов, которые спрятаны в лаборатории, в зависимости от сложности, иногда они просто на видном месте.
Так что надо обшарить все ящики, шкафы и полки.
Кроме ингредиентов, также спрятаны и подсказки, как из одного химиката получить другой, используя химический процессор, кодовый комбайн и микроволновку.
Для получения лекарства нужно подготовить три ключевых компонента, а создание каждого ключа это цепочка превращений и смешиваний различных компонентов.

Вроде бы звучит все просто, нашел, смешал и все готово, только время поджимает.

И ко всему прочему уменьшение роста будет оказывать сильное влияние, так как вы и до полки с приборами можете не дотянуться.
Так что придется запрыгивать на стулья, подтаскивать ящики, вообщем приспосабливаться.
Но с уменьшением роста, ваши силы тоже уменьшаются, так что ящик в определенный момент станет неподъемным.
А если не повезет то ящик может оказаться на вас и силенок его поднять не хватит. Забавная ситуация.

Вообщем все рассчитано на то, чтобы быстро искать, быстро соображать и быстро смешивать, но не взбалтывать.

Кстати, если вы вдруг нахимичили неизвестную субстанцию, то есть Ревертер, который поможет вернуть исходники, правда при этом придется потратить драгоценное время.

Игра выполнена с довольно приятной графикой, на реализм конечно не претендует, но смотрится гармонично, а главное идея с уменьшением по-моему оригинальна.
Наличие разных локаций тоже радует, особенно домашняя обстановка, где вы словно домовой бродите по квартире и пытаетесь что-то нахимичить.

Recommandé
0.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 février 2022
Got this in a bundle a while ago and thought I should leave a review. The basic concept of the game is that you are a scientist who has drunk a shrinking potion, and you need to brew the antidote before you shrink into nothingness. The more time you take, the harder it will be to complete the antidote due to your size – so you will need to stack boxes and prepare the room so that you can reach your instruments and navigate when you get smaller.

I had a lot of fun with it. If you are worried about the potion recipes being very complicated, don’t. It is more of a time-management race-against-the-clock game rather than something you have to memorize recipes. The main challenge comes from finding all the recipe pieces and managing all the ingredients, and just trying to figure out what combines with what. There is nothing really to tell you “yeah this potion is in the third stage of the recipe, that is why you don’t have it yet” you have to figure that out by looking at everything in front of you.

There aren’t really levels, it is mainly just different difficulty settings, but these can kind of be thought of as levels since going from beginner to normal mode doubled the amount of potions, so I imagine harder difficulties make it even more hectic. I also saw some of the difficulties down the line had modifiers like low gravity.

This is definitely a pretty cool game, I would check it out if you are interested (especially on sale). Also I feel like this game would work really well as a VR port.

Évaluation publiée le 28 novembre 2021
Size Matters is a procedural puzzle game. All the fun of a science textbook with a time limit! Wait... That's not a good sales pitch.

You play a shrinking scientist and must make the antidote. This requires finding all the formulas, making them, and winning. The game gets increasingly more complex with each difficultly level and allows you to customize your challenge.

Controls well enough, would like to see gamepad support. Currently the game only offers M+KB controls.

Could use a multiplayer mode. Even though the single player content is varied, this would make a great 'communication' style co-op game. Even two scientists who have to coordinate between labs. Sending ingredients back and forth while working together to create the cure.

Évaluation publiée le 18 septembre 2021
👍 I don't want to write a review for this game, but I do want to give this game a thumbs up to help the games ratings because I enjoyed my experience with it 👍

I didn't personally think this game was anything special for me personally. But I do think this game was pretty alright, and I think a good amount of people will very much so enjoy this.

I decided I was all good with the game after beating each 6 difficulty levels. But for those who want more, there is a lot of customizable sliders that allow you to change a significant amount mechanics in the game. As well as even enabling some things not found in the 6 difficulties.

I think for those who enjoy making their own challenges and beating them, you will really like this game. There's a lot of freedom in customizing your experience and many labs to play on.

My biggest problem with the game is that the like, physics stuff is a bit janky.
The only way I know how to explain this, is like youtuber janky physics stuff that's found in I Am Bread, Surgeon Simulator, Goat Simulator, Human Fall Flat.

I honestly hate games that have those annoying physics intentionally to slip you up as it annoyingly inhibits your ability to do your intended actions, with things out of your control.

Thankfully Size Matters tones that nonsense down to manageable degrees where it just becomes a small annoyance to accept and plan around. Rather than match ruining B.S that shaves off a bunch of time or constantly has you retrying a what should be, a simple action, multiple times.

All in all, it was a pretty good game. I recommend it. May not be all that worth it for people not into highly customizable content.
As you can see above, I only got 3 hours out of this game. So if you're not planning to do plenty of custom games, I highly recommend you buy it on sale.

Anyways, I hope this helps aid your decision on whether you want to buy this game or not. Have a good day.
 
Pachunea🍁

Évaluation publiée le 3 aout 2021
This is a fun puzzle game that you can play in short bursts from time to time. You're goal is to make an antidote for your shrinking predicament, but strangely this isn't well explained in game. You figure it out pretty easily, though. Puzzles involve looking for clues, which basically amount to formula for making oddly named compounds. Eventually you can form keys with enough clues, which can be combined into the antidote. The shrinking mechanic offers a fun and clever way of limiting your time so you can't brute force solutions.

Évaluation publiée le 25 juillet 2021
El juego está bien, el problema es que se llega a hacer repetitivo.
El objetivo es fácil, combinar todos los ingredientes hasta obtener tres llaves mientras te vas encogiendo. Lo bueno de cuando te vas encogiendo es que puedes mover objetos para que te ayuden a llegar a sitios altos.

Está el combinador que combina 2 elementos en uno. Está el microondas que te crea un nuevo elemento a partir del que le pongas. Y por último está el que va ♥♥♥ contraseña, metes un elemento y pones la clave que toque y te genera un nuevo elemento.

A parte de estas máquinas hay 2 más. Una es para retroceder una mezcla de dos elementos y la otra es para recuperar viales que se hayan roto o derramado.

Hay varios presets de dificultad y además te puedes hacer tu partida personalizada. Esto es muy útil si te quieres sacar todos los logros.

La única pega que le veo es que a veces hay que esperar mucho cuando tienes que combinar elementos. También otra cosa que me ha molestado es que cuando coges las fórmulas, si las tocas se quitan automáticamente, pero ♥♥♥ los viales esto no pasa.

Sólo recomiendo comprarlo cuando esté rebajado, a precio normal ni en broma me lo compraría. Y se pueden conseguir todos los logros muy fácilmente.

Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2021
Fun little distraction game. Got it in a Humble Choice bundle. Basic premise is, you're in a lab, find the chemicals, find the formulas (which tell you to put which chemical in which processor), repeat until you create 3 "keys" that go into an antidote machine. Oh, also you are shrinking throughout the whole process and you have to do all of this before you shrink into nothing. Difficulty in the game is set by a few various sliders (how fast you shrink, are chemicals breakable, etc.). There are 6 preset difficulties (tutorial, normal, hard, crazy, low gravity, tiny) plus a custom mode where you can set each slider.

For me, the basic game play is fun for a quick 5 minute take a break from work distraction, but I did enjoy hunting down the 57 achievements which aren't too difficult, but give you a reason to keep playing.

Évaluation publiée le 27 juin 2021
You can experience pretty much everything this game has to offer in one to two hours. While it works in desktop it's probably an idea that would be more suited to VR, where the main gimmick is more perceptible with the added immersion of virtual reality. Too content-lite to really be a justifiable purchase at full price with the increased difficulties not adding much more than the time it takes to complete tasks. You can have more complex formulas, but that is limited by only three devices that effect potions which makes it shallow. Other than that there are options to make potions spillable and breakable, but spillage is usually a victim of the games collision when picking things up and breakability doesn't add much more depth.

It's a great idea, but only really scratches the surface.

Évaluation publiée le 17 juin 2021
I expected to hate this due the whole game consisting of timed puzzles, but I ended up loving it.

Good
- Addictive gameplay. It's not stressful despite the time limit. It's actually very forgiving and you can still win even after you've become 30cm tall. And it's actually fun to figure out what to do with each ingredient.
- Lots of settings. You can set the timer all the way up to 60 minutes, and you can set your starting height, strength, double/triple jump ability and lots of other things however you please.

Neutral
- Easy achievements. I got 100% in four hours.
- No co-op. I personally don't care for any kind of multiplayer, but this game could benefit from a co-op mode.

Bad
- Lack of variety. You have six small laboratories to choose from, and they all have the same goal, equipment, etc.
- The usual physics problems that are present in every physics based first person game. Luckily you can turn off breakable vials in the settings.
